"For God so loved the world, that He gave His only begotten Son, that whoever believes in Him shall not perish, but have eternal life. For God did not send the Son into the world to judge the world, but that the world might be saved through Him. He who believes in Him is not judged; he who does not believe has been judged already, because he has not believed in the name of the only begotten Son of God. This is the judgment, that the Light has come into the world, and men loved the darkness rather than the Light, for their deeds were evil. For everyone who does evil hates the Light, and does not come to the Light for fear that his deeds will be exposed. But he who practices the truth comes to the Light, so that his deeds may be manifested as having been wrought in God."

May all personally encounter the presence and attention of the Lord God. 

Curiosity, questions, discussion, and prayer requests are welcome.

body:
He who began a good work... 

Not all who call on Jesus will be saved (the sinners prayer has created many false converts), but each of us is either saved by Christ or not at all. None of us (who are saved) earned our salvation and none of us (who are saved) can lose it.

If a Christian can lose their salvation, what works did they do to keep it? What praise will be bestowed on those wonderful beings who were able to hold their salvation tight, while others lost it? Do we boast in our works or in Christ? If in Christ, then are we not safe with Him? Or would He drop us?

As for me and my house, we will trust the LORD for our salvation and not our own works. For works do not save, but they are fruit.

body: Does it really matter whether someone loses their faith or was never really saved in the first place? The end result is the same, I don't understand all the fuss over it. It sounds like a vain argument to me, and while we're wasting time on this we could be doing something more worthwhile. I was going to quote Jesus when he said "The question is not how many are going to be saved. The question is, are you saved?" in Luke 13, but it appears to have been hit with the Mandela Effect and the conversation is now cut off with the initial narrow gate parable without the second dialogue. If it flips back (and that happens a lot) I'll try to remember to let you know (minor changes in the Bible that don't affect the meaning are surprisingly common, another recent one is that Paul never said "when in Rome, I do as the Romans do" in 1 Corinthians 9 and the quote is now attributed to Augustine. Paul now only says Jews, those with the law, those without the law, and the weak. Most famously is the lion and the lamb in Revelation is now wolf and lamb).

body:
One more thing, some of this is just ridiculous. For instance:

> Here, Paul explains to BORN AGAIN believers at the Church of Corinth, that A POOR DIET will send them to Hell!
> 
> ----------
> 
> For he that eateth and drinketh unworthily, eateth and drinketh damnation to himself, not discerning the Lord's body.
> 
> 1 Corinthians 11:29

Classic taking verses out of context again. That entire passage is about the *Lord's supper*, or communion. They are behaving unworthily during the communion. Also the more proper translation here would be judgement or condemnation, not necessarily damnation.

> Hebrews 6:4-7

> Hebrews 10:26-31

We don't know who wrote Hebrews. That doesn't make it false, but that doesn't give it good reputation either. This doctrine is not found anywhere else.

> But I keep under my body, and bring it into subjection: lest that by any means, when I have preached to others, I myself should be a castaway.
> 
> 1 Corinthians 9:27

This is a false translation. The correct term is "disqualified" not "castaway", and it's in relation to the prize mentioned earlier. A big issue with the Corinthians is that they took "all things are lawful for me" too far and indulged in that which is not beneficial. That doesn't make the former statement false, it just means the Corinthians abused it.

> He that saith, I know him, and keepeth not his commandments, is a liar, and the truth is not in him.
> 
> 1 John 2:4

That is about you, who is breaking several commandments, namely being so boastful and sure about your righteousness, and judging those who don't live up to your standards which are mostly made-up.

> EVERYONE that's NOT born again will go to Hell, but if a BORN AGAIN Christian backslides to a certain point, not only will they go to Hell - their punishment will be WORSE than the punishment of unbelievers!

Not true, only if they decide to reject Christ knowing full well who he is (blasphemy of the Holy Spirit).

> For if after they have escaped the pollutions of the world through the knowledge of the Lord and Saviour Jesus Christ, they are again entangled therein, and overcome, the latter end is worse with them than the beginning. For it had been better for them not to have known the way of righteousness, than, after they have known it, to turn from the holy commandment delivered unto them. But it is happened unto them according to the true proverb, The dog is turned to his own vomit again; and the sow that was washed to her wallowing in the mire.
> 
> 2 Peter 2:20-22

2 Peter is a forgery that teaches false doctrines. While it is true that the one who has knowledge of the truth and rejects it is worse off than before (blasphemy of the Holy Spirit) it is only through deliberate rejection and contempt that this is the case, not by slipping up as you seem to think.

> Not every one that saith unto me, Lord, Lord, shall enter into the kingdom of heaven; but he that doeth the will of my Father which is in heaven.
> 
> Matthew 7:21

Yes, by having a change of heart which also means you will naturally follow the commandments. Not your legalistic nonsense. In fact, if you are only obeying to "get into heaven" and not out of heart, you are not obeying them at all!

> Then said one unto him, Lord, are there few that be saved? And he said unto them, Strive to enter in at the strait gate: for many, I say unto you, will seek to enter in, and shall not be able.
> 
> Luke 13:23-24

Yes, the ones pleading their WORKS as the reason to enter.

> Thou believest that there is one God; thou doest well: the devils also believe, and tremble. But wilt thou know, O vain man, that faith without works is dead?
> 
> James 2:19-20

James is a forgery and it's clearly written by Jews who wanted to revert Christianity back to their system of works salvation. Jesus is barely even mentioned in the whole right-strawy epistle.

Look, I can play this game too!

> To some who were confident of their own righteousness and looked down on everyone else, Jesus told this parable: “Two men went up to the temple to pray, one a Pharisee and the other a tax collector. The Pharisee stood by himself and prayed: ‘God, I thank you that I am not like other people—robbers, evildoers, adulterers—or even like this tax collector. I fast twice a week and give a tenth of all I get.’ But the tax collector stood at a distance. **He would not even look up to heaven, but beat his breast and said, ‘God, have mercy on me, a sinner.’ I tell you that this man, rather than the other, went home justified before God.** For all those who exalt themselves will be humbled, and those who humble themselves will be exalted.”

> **All things are lawful to me**, but not all things do benefit. All things are lawful to me, but I will not be mastered by anything.

> When Jesus had entered Capernaum, a centurion came to him, asking for help. “Lord,” he said, “my servant lies at home paralyzed, suffering terribly.” Jesus said to him, “Shall I come and heal him?” The centurion replied, “**Lord, I do not deserve to have you come under my roof**. But just say the word, and my servant\* will be healed. For I myself am a man under authority, with soldiers under me. I tell this one, ‘Go,’ and he goes; and that one, ‘Come,’ and he comes. I say to my servant, ‘Do this,’ and he does it.” When Jesus heard this, he was amazed and said to those following him, “**Truly I tell you, I have not found anyone in Israel with such great faith. I say to you that many will come from the east and the west, and will take their places at the feast with Abraham, Isaac and Jacob in the kingdom of heaven.** But the subjects of the kingdom will be thrown outside, into the darkness, where there will be weeping and gnashing of teeth.” Then Jesus said to the centurion, “Go! Let it be done just as you believed it would.” And his servant was healed at that moment.

\* very likely the centurion's *catamite* (ΠΑΙΣ). If that is indeed the case then the point of this story is made even stronger, as we can no longer twist "I do not deserve to have you come under my roof" into merely a humble statement.

> Many will say to me on that day, ‘**Lord, Lord, did we not prophesy in your name and in your name drive out demons and in your name perform many miracles?**’ Then I will tell them plainly, ‘I never knew you. Away from me, you evildoers!’

---

Edit: Guess I'm too much for you eh?

![](https://i.ruqqus.com/post/6nfg/6EqnJcQLPxs)
